turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: We'll hear argument next in number oh oh eight four five two, Daryl Renard Atkins versus Vir- Spectators are admonished, do not talk until you get out of the courtroom, the court is still in session.
Mr. Ellis.
[Inaudible]

turn.speaker: james_w_ellis
turn.label: Mr. James W. Ellis
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court.

In nineteen eighty-nine, this Court, surveying the already growing evidence from a variety of sources that the people of this country oppose the execution of individuals with mental retardation, observed that that growing sentiment might someday be manifested in legislation, particularly by the States, which this Court identified as the sort of evidence upon which it typically can rely in Eighth Amendment cases.
The evidence is now clear that the American people in every region of the country have reached a consensus on that question.
By every measurement and through a th- course of legislative enactments that is literally unprecedented in the field of capital punishment...

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: What is your definition of a consensus, Mr. Ellis?

turn.speaker: james_w_ellis
turn.label: Mr. James W. Ellis
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, the I would define consensus, and this Court has discussed it in various terms in the cases, but I would distill from the cases in which the Court has described it that it is when the American people have reached a settled judgment based on...

turn.speaker: james_w_ellis
turn.label: Mr. James W. Ellis
turn.text: a mor-
Yes,

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: but I I tha- that's that's a f- perfectly sound phrase, but how do we go about figuring out when that occurs? I mean, how many States must be on a particular side? Does the population make any difference? H- How about those factors?

turn.speaker: james_w_ellis
turn.label: Mr. James W. Ellis
turn.text: Your Honor, there i- there has never been a suggestion by this Court that it differentiates among States with regard to size, and yet obviously logically if if an an if a collection of statutes only was found in the smallest of the States or the States o- of a single particular region, it would cut against the evidence that there was a consensus.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: And and h- how m- how many States out of the fifty do you need, do you think, for for a consensus?

turn.speaker: james_w_ellis
turn.label: Mr. James W. Ellis
turn.text: This Court has never suggested that there's a particular number in response to that.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: vary.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: but y- o- y- you're saying there is a consensus.

turn.speaker: james_w_ellis
turn.label: Mr. James W. Ellis
turn.text: I'm no- I'm not submitting on the basis of a figure, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Should we not look at legislative enactments as the surest indicator of what the view of the the particular State is?

turn.speaker: james_w_ellis
turn.label: Mr. James W. Ellis
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor, I think that you should, and I took that to be the the the teaching of this Court's opinion in the first Penry case.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: And looking at that, where do we stand today? We have how many States have no death penalty at all? Is it...

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: twelve?

turn.speaker: james_w_ellis
turn.label: Mr. James W. Ellis
turn.text: it's r- it's roughly twelve.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But, it in...

turn.speaker: james_w_ellis
turn.label: Mr. James W. Ellis
turn.text: part depends on how Vermont is counted, but...

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: but but as you...

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: States have now enacted legislation providing that a retarded person may not suffer the death penalty?

turn.speaker: james_w_ellis
turn.label: Mr. James W. Ellis
turn.text: There're now eighteen States as compared to the two that w- that were on the books or were about to go on the books, in the case of Maryland, when this Court decided the Penry case.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Of course, not a- n- not all of those eighteen feel so strongly that it is unconstitutional to execute someone with reduced mental capacity that they are willing to apply that to people who've already been sentenced.

turn.speaker: james_w_ellis
turn.label: Mr. James W. Ellis
turn.text: A number of them.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: categorization on the w- with your precise number...

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: that doesn't bespeak such a such an intransigent view that this is unconstitutional.

turn.speaker: james_w_ellis
turn.label: Mr. James W. Ellis
turn.text: I I guess I would characterize, Justice Scalia, the the statutes not as having concluded that the practice was unconstitutional, but instead that it was unacceptable.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: still...

turn.speaker: james_w_ellis
turn.label: Mr. James W. Ellis
turn.text: leaves your...

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: point.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: doesn't.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: They're just...

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: not going to do it in the future.

turn.speaker: james_w_ellis
turn.label: Mr. James W. Ellis
turn.text: I I I would respectfully suggest that they have not reached that judgment.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: H-

turn.speaker: james_w_ellis
turn.label: Mr. James W. Ellis
turn.text: and might've...

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: al-

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: do we know that? How do we know that?

turn.speaker: james_w_ellis
turn.label: Mr. James W. Ellis
turn.text: The the discussion in the l- th- t- in State legislatures, there isn't legislative history in quite the way there is in Congress, where...

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: people...

turn.speaker: james_w_ellis
turn.label: Mr. James W. Ellis
turn.text: deal differ- yeah I was going to say th- this must be a source of substantial disappointment.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Mr. Ellis, would would you would you agree I you know, I'm I'm not sure assuming I agree that that when there is a a a a new consensus that the Constitution means something it didn't mean before the Constitution means that new thing, assuming I agree with that, you you must agree that that we have to be very careful about finding new consensuses, don't you? Because w- we can't go back.

turn.speaker: james_w_ellis
turn.label: Mr. James W. Ellis
turn.text: I I would agree with you, Justice Scalia, that a- as the Court has said in various ways in several of the cases that the that the proponents of the view that there is a consensus bear an extraordinarily heavy burden of demonstration.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Well,

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: [Inaudible]

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Scalia's basic premise that it's a one-way ratchet is correct.

turn.speaker: james_w_ellis
turn.label: Mr. James W. Ellis
turn.text: This Court has not had had occasion to address that in particular.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, Mr.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Ellis, logically it has to be a one-way ratchet.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Of course, isn't it true that every new constitutional holding is a one-way ratchet in exactly the same way?

turn.speaker: james_w_ellis
turn.label: Mr. James W. Ellis
turn.text: W- n- not only in the area of the Eighth Amendment but in others as well.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Mr. Ellis I I guess...

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: there's no uniform determination of when someone should be regarded as mentally retarded.

turn.speaker: james_w_ellis
turn.label: Mr. James W. Ellis
turn.text: Justice O'Connor, they vary remarkably little.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: commitment.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: point is even if this Court were to say that he- it's unconstitutional to execute a person who's mentally retarded, presumably it would still be open to the State to determine whether that individual is mentally retarded under the State's definition, or is there some Federal definition you're asking us to employ?

turn.speaker: james_w_ellis
turn.label: Mr. James W. Ellis
turn.text: I- it seems to me that the States would be free to define mental retardation and, as I say, many use the definition they already have, that their clinicians are accustomed to a- so long as the definition they chose carried with it the core principles of the definition of mental retardation that this Court discussed in Penry, that is to say, m- a measured intelligence in the bottom i- i- two percent bul- bu- in the bottom two and a half percent of the population or two standard deviations below the mean, plus an impact on the real world functioning of the individual...

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: and as...

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: links up to the consensus problem if you take I don't think a poll is relevant, but a- but assuming you took a poll and since you execute the ret- retarded, I think most people would have in in in mind an image of mental retardation which doesn't reflect the sophistication of the DSM which talks about mild retardation and defines somebody mi- who's mildly retarded as educable with an IQ of maybe as high as s- he- e- h- i- in that range of of seventy with with some w- with some room for statistical error.

turn.speaker: james_w_ellis
turn.label: Mr. James W. Ellis
turn.text: With regard to pr- with regard to details, as I suggested a moment ago, the- there there is room for some difference, but with regard to the core principles, which I take to be at the center of y- o- o- o- of your question, are th- we describing the same group of people...

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: james_w_ellis
turn.label: Mr. James W. Ellis
turn.text: what we've discovered in the States is that they've all come to essentially the same conclusion, which is all the people who fall within the AAMR or DSM four T R definition are the people that they chose to protect.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: functioning of...

turn.speaker: james_w_ellis
turn.label: Mr. James W. Ellis
turn.text: individuals with mental retardation yes, Your Honor the- there ther- other than parents parents I'd put aside there is, I think, no group in this country more aware of the variety among people with mental retardation and the levels of functioning at each level than State legislators.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Th- this goes to the where where is the burden of proof in a case like supposing your view is adopted, the State charges capital murder.

turn.speaker: james_w_ellis
turn.label: Mr. James W. Ellis
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Mr. Ellis, what about this very case? There was some confusion, but the Virginia Supreme Court seemed to doubt that this person would qualify as mentally retarded.

turn.speaker: james_w_ellis
turn.label: Mr. James W. Ellis
turn.text: W- O- obviously, in our w- we would not be totally disappointed if this Court were to resolve that question, but the the the the likelihood and prospect of a remand obviously would inapprop- be an appropriate response so that the Virginia courts who did not, in this case, have before them mental retardation as a legal question that was going to decide anything it was simply an observation in the course of making...

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: [Inaudible]

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: precisely did the Virginia Supreme Court say about this defendant and...

turn.speaker: james_w_ellis
turn.label: Mr. James W. Ellis
turn.text: I I I think maybe the th- the Virginia Supreme Court's chara- i- b- decision on that can be best characterized as expressing concern as to whether or not the individual in this case Mr. Atkins had mental retardation because of the testimony of Dr.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: definition...

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: [Inaudible]

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: apart from the consensus argument and these details, is- what is the real reason behind your position? Why what's wrong with executing the mentally retarded?

turn.speaker: james_w_ellis
turn.label: Mr. James W. Ellis
turn.text: In in our view, Your Honor, the people with mental retardation who have both that intellectual functioning as the core and it has manifested itself in their life throughout their life those individuals in our view lack the culpability or blame worthiness because their understanding of their actions, their understanding of the context in which their actions took place...

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Well, why are they subject to criminal liability at all then?

turn.speaker: james_w_ellis
turn.label: Mr. James W. Ellis
turn.text: they are subject to criminal liability because it isn't our contention that they, for example, can't tell i- e- to use the the language in in in Virginia's defense of insanity, that they can't tell right from wrong.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: So, nothing wrong with putting a retarded person we know that there's a problem with definition, but in in jail for life, or in solitary.

turn.speaker: james_w_ellis
turn.label: Mr. James W. Ellis
turn.text: N- n- no- nothing in the ruling that we seek here would preclude the State from imposing the most serious penalty it has other than the penalty of death.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: the heaviest penalty.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: be the same as for executing someone with a mental illness? We we have dealt with that, and and with the level of comprehension that someone must have in order to be eligible for the death penalty who has mental illness.

turn.speaker: james_w_ellis
turn.label: Mr. James W. Ellis
turn.text: Your Honor, I believe you're discus- discussing the Ford i- issue with regard to competence to be executed? I read the Ford case as suggesting that whether the individual had mental illness or mental retardation, if if that individual lacked the understanding as execution w- became imminent, that they w- that the State would be precluded from executing.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: situ-

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: that test not adequate here in your view?

turn.speaker: james_w_ellis
turn.label: Mr. James W. Ellis
turn.text: Th- that test, it seems to me, is not adequate for several reasons.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: What what about our ment- I what about our mental illness cases dealing with the time of the crime? Why aren't they sufficient to indeed excuse somebody who couldn't help themself? You're you're saying these people can help themselves.

turn.speaker: james_w_ellis
turn.label: Mr. James W. Ellis
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: functioning.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: of wh- I mean, they have to have known that what they were doing is wrong.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Right. Yes.

turn.speaker: james_w_ellis
turn.label: Mr. James W. Ellis
turn.text: in any of these States,

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: yes.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: isn't that the only thing that bears upon culpability?

turn.speaker: james_w_ellis
turn.label: Mr. James W. Ellis
turn.text: I- it s- seems to me, Your Honor, that it is not because because under our system of capital punishment, as it has been shaped by the decisions by this Court, we don't say that the death penalty is available for everyone who can be punished.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Yes, but but those rules were based upon the fact that some people are not as culpable.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: think it is.

turn.speaker: james_w_ellis
turn.label: Mr. James W. Ellis
turn.text: and I think it's untrue.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Yeah, I think it's totally untrue.

turn.speaker: james_w_ellis
turn.label: Mr. James W. Ellis
turn.text: S- so, what we're saying in in in response to to to to your question, what we are saying is that a person who commits an act who has mental retardation, who commits an act which is subject to punishment, does so within the scope of the limitations imposed by his disability.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: in in resp-

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: what is the reason? I mean, you you in in responding to Justice Scalia's question, you you point out, well, these people pass the the test of of comprehension, which is a a condition of culpability for execution.

turn.speaker: james_w_ellis
turn.label: Mr. James W. Ellis
turn.text: The principal reason, and and it has changed a little bit as as the as the process has gone on.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: appropriate punishment.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: realize that that's the judgment they're reaching, and you want us to recognize that judgment as now having constitutional significance.

turn.speaker: james_w_ellis
turn.label: Mr. James W. Ellis
turn.text: And and as I said, th- the principal focus is on the understanding of people of what the limitations imposed on people with mental retardation are and how it affects they th- their comprehension...

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: and understanding. Yes.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Is that the idea?

turn.speaker: james_w_ellis
turn.label: Mr. James W. Ellis
turn.text: It it it is it is that their understanding of the wrongness of their action may be incomplete and in a sense immature in the same way or in a parallel way at least...

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: [Inaudible]

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Ellis, I thought that you had said something different in your brief, and it was that people in this class have diminished capacity when it comes to the life or death decision.

turn.speaker: james_w_ellis
turn.label: Mr. James W. Ellis
turn.text: And and and that was the point I was adverting to w- was adverting to a moment ago, that the principal reason is, as I've suggested, the the shared understanding of the diminished culpability of people with mental retardation.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Counsel is not able to bring that to the jury's attention...

turn.speaker: james_w_ellis
turn.label: Mr. James W. Ellis
turn.text: C- counsel...

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: and say, ladies and gentlemen of the jury i- in fact, he can bring mental retardation to the attention of the jury as a basis for the j- f- for the jury's deciding not to execute the person, c- can can he not?

turn.speaker: james_w_ellis
turn.label: Mr. James W. Ellis
turn.text: He clearly can.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: There's no question that in all States he can do that.

turn.speaker: james_w_ellis
turn.label: Mr. James W. Ellis
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: So, you're saying the jury is not constitutionally even allowed to to be given the option.

turn.speaker: james_w_ellis
turn.label: Mr. James W. Ellis
turn.text: There there may well be cases in which that would be effective in guarding against that concern, but that also backs into the problem this Court observed in Penry, which is in a case-by-case determination, particularly in cases in which juries are making the decision, the mental retardation may in fact be a two-edged sword, that the that the that the juror, in evaluating whether or not to impose the penalty of death, may see mental retardation not only as a mitigating or potentially mitigating factor, but it may also see it as tied to prospective dangerousness.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: States...

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: in all cases of mental illness as well?

turn.speaker: james_w_ellis
turn.label: Mr. James W. Ellis
turn.text: I- is is is is the difficulty o- of case-by-case? Yes.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Your arguments seem to be equally applicable to those who are mentally ill.

turn.speaker: james_w_ellis
turn.label: Mr. James W. Ellis
turn.text: It it is but unlike mental ill- e- i- in in the case of mental illness, unlike mental retardation, there has not been a manifestation of a national consensus, either in legislation or elsewhere, that suggests the American people have...

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: rejected the notion.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: reasons you put forward to us seem to me remarkably the same.

turn.speaker: james_w_ellis
turn.label: Mr. James W. Ellis
turn.text: The th- the...

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Am I right?

turn.speaker: james_w_ellis
turn.label: Mr. James W. Ellis
turn.text: w- would apply to other defendants who don't have mental retardation.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Right.

turn.speaker: james_w_ellis
turn.label: Mr. James W. Ellis
turn.text: But but they are not so closely tied to the defining characteristics of a class as they are here to have produced that...

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: consensus...

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: So come back and tell us how we know when there's a consensus.

turn.speaker: james_w_ellis
turn.label: Mr. James W. Ellis
turn.text: Your Honor, it seems to me that I read this Court's cases as saying that they will th- that the Court will look to that t- that in prospective cases you will look to a variety of forms of evidence, but that any proffer of evidence of a consensus which does not have substantial and ther- in one case a discussion of recent formulation of that consensus into enactments by the legislature will be viewed with skepticism or impact more...

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: How many States still allow the execution of retarded?

turn.speaker: james_w_ellis
turn.label: Mr. James W. Ellis
turn.text: Theoretically there there could be twenty.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: In how many of those States have there been executions of retarded people since Penry the...

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: last twenty years? I count two.

turn.speaker: james_w_ellis
turn.label: Mr. James W. Ellis
turn.text: we we cannot be sure but it is roughly two or three, yes.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: So, you you have less less than half of the States that have ca- capital punishment make an exception for the mentally retarded, and you say that that constitutes a...

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: consensus. Less than half.

turn.speaker: james_w_ellis
turn.label: Mr. James W. Ellis
turn.text: N- not by itself.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: I I can see the argument that there's a consensus on the other side since the other side seems to be in the majority, but you say less than half represents a consensus.

turn.speaker: james_w_ellis
turn.label: Mr. James W. Ellis
turn.text: I I'm not sure that that that we could conclude, for example, that people in the States that don't have the death penalty approve its imposition or if they adopted a death penalty would include within the scope...

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: [Inaudible]

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: legislation, and and we...

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: forty-eight constituted a...

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: consensus.

turn.speaker: james_w_ellis
turn.label: Mr. James W. Ellis
turn.text: Well, the that is that is another way i- of counting.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: [Inaudible]

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: we also said in Penry that you you know the argument was made to us that there was an emerging consensus, and we rejected that.

turn.speaker: james_w_ellis
turn.label: Mr. James W. Ellis
turn.text: And and our position, on the basis of what has happened in the thirteen years since Penry, is that the consensus that was then emerging is now manifest, both in the legislation and in every other indicator we have of public sentiment.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: you're not talking about polls if you're talking about public sentiment, are you?

turn.speaker: james_w_ellis
turn.label: Mr. James W. Ellis
turn.text: I- It seems to me, Your Honor, that the that the polling information, which was quite scanty then and is now quite full, as suggested in the AAMR amicus brief in McCarver, is part of the picture.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: [Inaudible]

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: expect if people feel that way, it would it would be manifested in legislation?

turn.speaker: james_w_ellis
turn.label: Mr. James W. Ellis
turn.text: And increasingly it is.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Yes, but are you saying that somehow polls are to be considered in addition to legislation?

turn.speaker: james_w_ellis
turn.label: Mr. James W. Ellis
turn.text: Polls, it seems to me, Your Honor are a way of of of viewing the legislation, of seeing whether or not the consensus the legislation appears to reveal is in fact...

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: [Inaudible]

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: it polls should be admitted in if we're going to talk about polls as contributing to this discussion, they should be admitted in the trial court and subject to examination by the other side.

turn.speaker: james_w_ellis
turn.label: Mr. James W. Ellis
turn.text: I d- I don't believe I I I I'm trying to think of a case in which polling has played a part in the trial court, and and I believe it has no- I w- none comes to mind.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Very well.

turn.speaker: pamela_a_rumpz
turn.label: Ms. Pamela A. Rumpz
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Well, the position of the Commonwealth of Virginia is that you can execute the retarded.

turn.speaker: pamela_a_rumpz
turn.label: Ms. Pamela A. Rumpz
turn.text: Yes, the retarded individuals who, like Atkins, were found competent at the time of the crime, competent at the time of to assist his lawyers, who were found guilty of a premeditated, deliberated, and calculated murder, and who...

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: So, any person who has criminal responsibility can be executed no matter how retarded they are.

turn.speaker: pamela_a_rumpz
turn.label: Ms. Pamela A. Rumpz
turn.text: That is the position of the Commonwealth of Virginia, yes.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: You w- you would not say no matter how retarded.

turn.speaker: pamela_a_rumpz
turn.label: Ms. Pamela A. Rumpz
turn.text: Exactly, Your Honor, but...

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: if But short of...

turn.speaker: pamela_a_rumpz
turn.label: Ms. Pamela A. Rumpz
turn.text: that, exactly.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: y- the-

turn.speaker: pamela_a_rumpz
turn.label: Ms. Pamela A. Rumpz
turn.text: the DSM TR four TR recognizes four different categories of mental retardation.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: We're ar-

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: say the same thing then about about children, about young people? So long as the State can prove the premeditation, the deliberation, the the other requirements of of of mental culpability, let them be executed.

turn.speaker: pamela_a_rumpz
turn.label: Ms. Pamela A. Rumpz
turn.text: But this Court has said that about sixteen-year-olds in Stanford.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Well, let's take five-year-olds.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Would would...

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: you argue that five-year-olds should be executed if if they have deliberated on on the on the act and and and otherwise the State can prove the the mental element?

turn.speaker: pamela_a_rumpz
turn.label: Ms. Pamela A. Rumpz
turn.text: I I think that that that that's an a p- unlikely to happen.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Do you believe there is there is any role at all in in the in Eighth Amendment jurisprudence, death penalty jurisprudence I guess, for for general rules to the effect that, yes, there may in some instances, let's say, of retardation be be proof of that would at least be enough to get to a jury on premeditation and and and deliberation and so on, but that the very fact of of retardation makes it unlikely in most cases that this can be proven and makes the evidence at least highly debatable, even in those cases that get to a jury? And therefore, the sensible thing to do in order to avoid a high risk either of wrong conviction or in the case of of the penalty phase a a high risk of of unsound judgments imposing the death penalty, there ought to be a cutoff point of some sort.

turn.speaker: pamela_a_rumpz
turn.label: Ms. Pamela A. Rumpz
turn.text: A high risk cutoff rule of I'm sorry I didn't follow...

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: exactly what you were saying...

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: I'm I'm assuming that that, sure, there are cases of borderline retardation and so on in which the the there would be enough evidence to get to a jury on the various mental elements for a for a capital sentencing.

turn.speaker: pamela_a_rumpz
turn.label: Ms. Pamela A. Rumpz
turn.text: That's what individualized sentencing is.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: That's what juries...

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: clear that within the category of those who ought to be subject to the death penalty, there should be individual assessment.

turn.speaker: pamela_a_rumpz
turn.label: Ms. Pamela A. Rumpz
turn.text: I I you know, I I don't want to play dumb here, Justice Souter, but I'm afraid I'm not understanding what what you're asking me.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: [Inaudible]

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: because I'd like to get the answer to Justice Souter's question myself let's assume.

turn.speaker: pamela_a_rumpz
turn.label: Ms. Pamela A. Rumpz
turn.text: Okay, I'll assume that.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Justice Justice Souter asked the question, if there is that risk, is there a place in our Eighth Amendment jurisprudence for us to take account of that risk and draw some lines?

turn.speaker: pamela_a_rumpz
turn.label: Ms. Pamela A. Rumpz
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Miss Rumpz, I I ma- it's a hard question to answer because I guess you you would need a definition of what constitutes an inappropriate or improper death penalty, and we haven't we haven't established any guidelines.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And...

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: scheme there there there there i-

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: there is not a proper or an improper death death sentence.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: I guess you're talking about a class...

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: of you said this class of people and I'm not sure you meant that is no less culpable than you or me.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: I I'll be ha-

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: But I want you to address, A, I've tried to make a point maybe they are not so culpable as you or me.

turn.speaker: pamela_a_rumpz
turn.label: Ms. Pamela A. Rumpz
turn.text: Well, first of all, I think this case is a perfect illustration of the first point, the first point being that that they are.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: So, you're looking...

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: time...

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: on that is you want to say less than eighteen.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: I sh- I sure do.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: want to know why not far more than eighteen, and my reason for that is that in of the remaining twenty see there are two States that have executed retarded people, and they account, I gather, for about seven percent of the population.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: to pass a law?

turn.speaker: pamela_a_rumpz
turn.label: Ms. Pamela A. Rumpz
turn.text: W- w- well, I I I think that that the fact that eighteen States have done so in the last thirteen years i- i- i- it doesn't mean...

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: that that...

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: those States were executing a lot of retarded people, and that's why the laws were passed.

turn.speaker: pamela_a_rumpz
turn.label: Ms. Pamela A. Rumpz
turn.text: Well, that's an equally good assumption.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Well, I assume a- an an even simpler assumption is that they were executing people.

turn.speaker: pamela_a_rumpz
turn.label: Ms. Pamela A. Rumpz
turn.text: I don't know what State you...

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: come from, first of all.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: I'm from New Hampshire, and the last execution was in thirty-eight or thirty-nine.

turn.speaker: pamela_a_rumpz
turn.label: Ms. Pamela A. Rumpz
turn.text: I I guess my answer to that is that this Court has said that societal consensuses are formed, and when you're looking to see whether there is a societal consensus, you look to the statutes that the that the...

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: legislators have passed.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: asking about, and and Jus- Justice Breyer's question, as well as Justice Souter's, is i- I think must recognize the premise that one of the great facts of life in American Government is legislative inertia.

turn.speaker: pamela_a_rumpz
turn.label: Ms. Pamela A. Rumpz
turn.text: Or there's no such person o- person on death row who was not competent to to to commit his crime, was not competent at the time of his trial, was not...

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: competent to assist his lawyers. There's a difference there.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: M- well what what do we know, Ms. Rumpz, about the situation in the States, the eighteen States which have prohibited the execution of the retarded? W- w- had they just gone through a tremendous number of retarded executions?

turn.speaker: pamela_a_rumpz
turn.label: Ms. Pamela A. Rumpz
turn.text: I suspect not.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: We- well do we kn- is there any anything in the briefs that indicates why these States w- passed the legislation that they did?

turn.speaker: pamela_a_rumpz
turn.label: Ms. Pamela A. Rumpz
turn.text: I- no, there's not.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: [Inaudible]

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: says only two mentally retarded people have been executed in in the last I don't know what.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: No, no.

turn.speaker: pamela_a_rumpz
turn.label: Ms. Pamela A. Rumpz
turn.text: Well, the Federal Death Penalty Information Center, if you get on their web site, says that since Penry was decided in nineteen eighty-nine, twenty-five mentally...

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: retarded people have been executed...

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: tried bit by bit, and i- most of them are in these States and then some of them are have IQs of seventy or over.

turn.speaker: pamela_a_rumpz
turn.label: Ms. Pamela A. Rumpz
turn.text: I I think just because two States in in in since nineteen eighty-nine have executed mentally retarded offenders doesn't mean that there aren't mentally retarded offen- retarded offenders in the pipeline waiting to be to become executed or waiting to go through their appellate process or or coming up to trial.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Well leave leave it at this, that since Penry Penry.

turn.speaker: pamela_a_rumpz
turn.label: Ms. Pamela A. Rumpz
turn.text: Well, I I guess I'd go back to what Justice Scalia said in one of his opinions is that that may very well just be that juries and prosecutors and society believes that the death penalty ought to be imposed on the mentally retarded less often.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Ms. Rumpz, if we stayed just with the eighteen plus the twelve that don't have the death penalty, then we get up to what?

turn.speaker: pamela_a_rumpz
turn.label: Ms. Pamela A. Rumpz
turn.text: Thirty.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Three-fifths of all the States.

turn.speaker: pamela_a_rumpz
turn.label: Ms. Pamela A. Rumpz
turn.text: For two reasons.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: N-

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: time in this Court wasn't all that long ago when this Court was making prospective declarations of unconstitutionality, this case and all future cases, not past cases.

turn.speaker: pamela_a_rumpz
turn.label: Ms. Pamela A. Rumpz
turn.text: W- even given that, New York has in its statute specifically that people who commit murders, while in prison, can be executed even if they're mentally retarded.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Why not?

turn.speaker: pamela_a_rumpz
turn.label: Ms. Pamela A. Rumpz
turn.text: Well, because they may have some bearing on whether there's an a a consensus against the death penalty altogether.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Right, and...

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: it...

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: includes that.

turn.speaker: pamela_a_rumpz
turn.label: Ms. Pamela A. Rumpz
turn.text: Well, t- i- Wisconsin tomorrow may decide to adopt a death penalty statute, and if they do, they'll have to affirmatively to affirmatively legislate a number of things.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Let me try this another way.

turn.speaker: pamela_a_rumpz
turn.label: Ms. Pamela A. Rumpz
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: You don't agree that if there's a consensus, then the Eighth Amendment would bar it.

turn.speaker: pamela_a_rumpz
turn.label: Ms. Pamela A. Rumpz
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: This Court said that might, indeed, be the law in Penry, but you say we were wrong there.

turn.speaker: pamela_a_rumpz
turn.label: Ms. Pamela A. Rumpz
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: the other States.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: accept the notion that if there is a consensus and we find there is, that that answers the question.

turn.speaker: pamela_a_rumpz
turn.label: Ms. Pamela A. Rumpz
turn.text: N- I I...

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: I think...

turn.speaker: pamela_a_rumpz
turn.label: Ms. Pamela A. Rumpz
turn.text: that Spaziano says different.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Well, do you accept the view that there is in fact an evolutionary element in Eighth Amendment jurisprudence, that in fact it does change as as as societal notions of reasonableness in terms of cruelty...

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: change?

turn.speaker: pamela_a_rumpz
turn.label: Ms. Pamela A. Rumpz
turn.text: has said that there're...

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: that there is.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: So...

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: the answer.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: right? That's That's...

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: the position I'm in too.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: You So you you ac- you ac- you accept that as the framework that we are supposed to be working in.

turn.speaker: pamela_a_rumpz
turn.label: Ms. Pamela A. Rumpz
turn.text: That's what that's what this Court said in...

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: May I ask...

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: another question on little different line? I think there's been sort of a consensus in the argument here that the number of executions of the mentally retarded is rather small.

turn.speaker: pamela_a_rumpz
turn.label: Ms. Pamela A. Rumpz
turn.text: Yes...

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: death And does not that reflect the fact that juries generally are reluctant to execute the mentally retarded, to p- impose the death penalty on the mentally retarded?

turn.speaker: pamela_a_rumpz
turn.label: Ms. Pamela A. Rumpz
turn.text: I I I'm I I don't know that that reflects that.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: the brief of the...

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: it is true, isn't i- is that not one of the facts on which the Court relied in the rape case, holding that the crime of race could not be command the death...

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: penalty.

turn.speaker: pamela_a_rumpz
turn.label: Ms. Pamela A. Rumpz
turn.text: This Court looks at the laws and the application of...

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: the laws...

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: the number of juries that refuse to impose the death penalty.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: right?

turn.speaker: pamela_a_rumpz
turn.label: Ms. Pamela A. Rumpz
turn.text: is exactly right.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: There are very few executions of women in the United States.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Absolutely not.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: so rarely impose it?

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: No, but it is...

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: it is part of our law.

turn.speaker: pamela_a_rumpz
turn.label: Ms. Pamela A. Rumpz
turn.text: Well, I...

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: think that the fact...

turn.speaker: pamela_a_rumpz
turn.label: Ms. Pamela A. Rumpz
turn.text: that we're here arguing this case today is proof that juries do, in fact, give the death penalty to mentally retarded people.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: pages of cases where...

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: never do.

turn.speaker: pamela_a_rumpz
turn.label: Ms. Pamela A. Rumpz
turn.text: And the fact that they rarely do, like I said earlier, could mean that juries believe, just as Atkins' team believes, that it sh- i- that it should be rarely imposed.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well it's it's saying...

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: m- may rep- represent a jury's belief that it is a mitigating circumstance of such force that they should be spared the death penalty.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Of course.

turn.speaker: pamela_a_rumpz
turn.label: Ms. Pamela A. Rumpz
turn.text: And I agree.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: N-

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: do y- in making this cruel and unusual decision this is an issue that's come up before, but does what the rest of the world thinks about e- executing the mentally retarded does should that have any relevance at all? I mean, we have, since the time we said we don't look to the rest of the world, been supporters of international human rights tribunals in for the former Yugoslavia, for the former Rwanda.

turn.speaker: pamela_a_rumpz
turn.label: Ms. Pamela A. Rumpz
turn.text: This Court has said previously that the notions of other countries and the notions of other lands cannot play the deciding factor...

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: in what...

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: I asked you if it was relevant.

turn.speaker: pamela_a_rumpz
turn.label: Ms. Pamela A. Rumpz
turn.text: Well, i- it is relevant in i- as Justice Scalia said in one of his p- opinions, to determine whether our practice is a historical accident or not.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Most of the world would not execute rocket scientists.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: I mean would not execute rocket scientists.

turn.speaker: pamela_a_rumpz
turn.label: Ms. Pamela A. Rumpz
turn.text: of th- of the co- of the of the planet i-

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: is...

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: abolish the death...

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: penalty. That's if...

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: that's to be a...

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: consid- if it's...

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: relevant.

turn.speaker: pamela_a_rumpz
turn.label: Ms. Pamela A. Rumpz
turn.text: And...

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: and...

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: ask if it was dispositive.

turn.speaker: pamela_a_rumpz
turn.label: Ms. Pamela A. Rumpz
turn.text: It's not dispositive, and it is relevant once the Eighth Amendment principle has already been established.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Why do you need it after it's been established?

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: You don't...

turn.speaker: pamela_a_rumpz
turn.label: Ms. Pamela A. Rumpz
turn.text: You don't.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: That's what I thought.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: It's It's not relevant.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: I I did not have a chance to ask petitioner's counsel because his rebuttal time was running up, but it's important to me.

turn.speaker: pamela_a_rumpz
turn.label: Ms. Pamela A. Rumpz
turn.text: I don't know, and and it w-

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: there...

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: same as the general population or higher?

turn.speaker: pamela_a_rumpz
turn.label: Ms. Pamela A. Rumpz
turn.text: I I I I couldn't...

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: speculate. We...

turn.speaker: pamela_a_rumpz
turn.label: Ms. Pamela A. Rumpz
turn.text: don't know and it's not in this record what the what the prison population of mental retarded people...

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: are...

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: is the status of the legislation in Virginia on this point now?

turn.speaker: pamela_a_rumpz
turn.label: Ms. Pamela A. Rumpz
turn.text: It was it didn't pass the House.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: It passed one house but not the other?

turn.speaker: pamela_a_rumpz
turn.label: Ms. Pamela A. Rumpz
turn.text: Passed bicameral legislature Virginia.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Was it voted on in the House?

turn.speaker: pamela_a_rumpz
turn.label: Ms. Pamela A. Rumpz
turn.text: I don't...

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: know...

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: thought it wasn't voted on.

turn.speaker: pamela_a_rumpz
turn.label: Ms. Pamela A. Rumpz
turn.text: I don't believe it was voted on.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: in two years...

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: pendulum swing when it's all in the same direction? I thought a pendulum went back and forth.

turn.speaker: pamela_a_rumpz
turn.label: Ms. Pamela A. Rumpz
turn.text: It's a pendulum swing one way.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: It only goes in one direction at a time, doesn't it?

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Becaus-

turn.speaker: pamela_a_rumpz
turn.label: Ms. Pamela A. Rumpz
turn.text: B- But my point is this practice has been allowed since the Bill of Rights was adopted in seventeen eighty-nine, and we have eighteen States, some of which can't decide in between themselves whether the mentally retarded should or shouldn't be executed, with an average age of five years.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: that just didn't work.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: that there's a consensus and want to argue it's just not enduring? Or what is it you're...

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: arguing?

turn.speaker: pamela_a_rumpz
turn.label: Ms. Pamela A. Rumpz
turn.text: I I I I think there's not a consensus, first of all, and my backup position is if there is a consensus, it certainly isn't one of an enduring nature.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Thank you, Ms. Rumpz.

turn.speaker: james_w_ellis
turn.label: Mr. James W. Ellis
turn.text: I'll endeavor to answer couple of the questions that this Court had raised.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Thank you, Mr. Ellis.

turn.speaker: the_marshal
turn.label: Mr. The Marshal
turn.text: The honorable court is now adjourned until Monday next at ten o'clock.
